body: Whether it's premultiplied or not seems to be completely unspecified; that sounds like an issue.
You specify non-premultiplied alpha data, as can be seen with the animated cursor in the `cursor` test.

issue.title: Q: Is the image format for icons image.RGBA?
issue.body:
https://github.com/go-gl/glfw/blob/master/v3.2/glfw/window.go#L345

Does all platforms support pre-multiplied alpha RGBA instead of non-pre-multiplied alpha RGBA (NRGBA)? I feel like NRGBA is correct but am not sure.

issue.title: GLFWimage under-documented

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Bug reports and bugfix pull requests

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
http://www.glfw.org/docs/latest/structGLFWimage.html

GLFWimage::pixels is documented as:

"The pixel data of this image, arranged left-to-right, top-to-bottom."

This gives no indication of the number of color channel components or their layout (RGB or BGR?  Alpha?)

issue.title: v3.2/glfw: Use and document *image.NRGBA as expected image format.
issue.body:
GLFW images are non-premultiplied RGBA, which corresponds to `*image.NRGBA` type. This was previously not documented in GLFW, but has since been fixed in glfw/glfw#426 and glfw/glfw#1027.

This is not a breaking API change and functionality is preserved. However, for optimal performance (to avoid unnecessary conversions), images should now ideally be provided as `*image.NRGBA` rather than `*image.RGBA`.

Fixes #209. /cc @hajimehoshi

issue.title: wait until Vsync API

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
I'd like to do my rendering and processing just before each Vsync, to reduce latency. So if a frame takes 0.1s, then my application will wait for 0.08s after the last Vsync, then render and process everything in the next 0.01s, so that the frame is only 0.02s old when it is pulled. This is only possible if GLFW has a function for reporting when the Vsync happened, such as GetTimeSinceLastVSync or WaitForVSync. With this information, I can measure the time between frames, measure my render loop's time, and then insert my rendering at the appropriate location just before the Vsync.

The advantage over single buffering is less CPU usage, and the advantage over double buffering is less latency.

VR implementation: https://developer.oculus.com/blog/optimizing-vr-graphics-with-late-latching/ calls it "late-latching" and states that consoles have had it for a long time
VR implementation: http://media.steampowered.com/apps/valve/2015/Alex_Vlachos_Advanced_VR_Rendering_GDC2015.pdf P20-22. uses [IDXGIOutput::WaitForVBlank](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb174559(v=vs.85).aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396#) on Windows. Their presentation talks about GPU rendering start points which is different, and they want the end of VSync rather than the beginning, but their timepoint API serves the same purpose, lowering latency.
recent: https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/q/151893
